Comment: I hear you, but for the record (if you’re talking US), you as a civilian can absolutely not get a flamethrower easily. What you are most likely referring to (like the Elon “flame thrower”) is actually just a glorified blow torch/weed torch. The distinction being, a flame thrower actually *throws* flaming fuel at a distance. Those weed torches are just big lighters— localized flame burning fuel, with a limited range.   The reason why you can buy one of those *flame throwers* easily is because it was deemed to have a legitimate legal purpose with as limited danger to the public as possible, given the fiery context. The same goes for those “few dollars of gas” — legitimate purpose with as limited dangers as possible.   The reason you can’t get a *real* flamethrower easily (there are certain contexts under which a civilian can own one, like for controlled burns by forestry services) is because it’s deemed a destructive device — something with little to no legitimate legal purpose (like self defense) and a lot of potential to cause harm.   I get your point that it’s still possible to burn a house down with gas, but as easy as that may be, it’s not flamethrower easy. As discussed we can’t stop people from buying gas. We can stop them from having flamethrowers.   Automatic weapons are not dissimilar in my mind in that regard— little to no legitimate legal purpose that is not already accomplished by the fire arms we already have access to, and far too dangerous in the wrong hands to be worth the upsides. Yes you can still shoot people with a semi-auto, and I personally believe we make that too easy, but if you know anyone who has used automatic weapons, I don’t think they would even argue much about just how big an increase in destructive power full autos are. Differences like 50-60 rounds per min vs. potentially hundreds. I get they’re cool and fun to shoot, but they’re just not worth the trade off to the public in favor of fun range days and perhaps some belief that one day you might have to over throw a dictatorship.

Comment: There are zero laws restricting the ownership of a flamethrower in the United States. They are less restricted than firearms, even the really powerful ones. [Here's a website selling them.](https://throwflame.com/)  Machine guns meanwhile are NFA items, and are highly restricted. Not only do I need to go through the same process as getting any other firearm to buy one. I need a background check, can't be a felon, or several other things. Beyond that I need an NFA stamp, which requires a $200 fee, and an enhanced background check. The registry was also closed in 1986, with only guns manufactured and registered prior to that being grandfathered in. So there are a limited number of fully automatic guns available, and you're looking at the low 5 figures minimum to buy one.
